title: When Mild Hearing Loss Accompanies Mild Cognitive Impairment
chief_complaint: I don't think I have any significant difficulty with hearing or daily communication, but my wife says I'm asking for repetition more often.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual decrease over the past few years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Social withdrawal, difficulty with word-finding and remembering names (related to MCI).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient is participating less in social conversations (e.g., family dinners). Wife reports communication is becoming stressful.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is high-functioning (court interpreter, cantor) and wants to maintain this lifestyle; motivated by wife's concerns and link between hearing and cognition.

history.present_illness: Referred by geriatrician following a diagnosis of Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) 1 month prior. Geriatrician noted hearing loss is a risk factor for cognitive decline. Patient denies hearing issues; wife reports frequent repetition and social withdrawal.
history.otologic_history: No ear pain, drainage, surgery, or tinnitus. History of vertigo attributed to low blood pressure. Previous hearing test 6 months ago described as 'borderline normal'.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with amnestic MCI (MoCA score 25/30). Family history of Alzheimer's (mother). Cataracts and bifocals.
history.patient_goals: Identified needs via COSI: Hearing in court (job), synagogue (cantor), family dinners, and watching TV.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral, slightly asymmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Normal thresholds through 1000 Hz, sloping to moderate (Right) and moderately-severe (Left) in the high frequencies.

numeric_results.Bone_Conduction: Symmetric with AC thresholds (no air-bone gaps).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) indicate mild loss. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent/normal in quiet.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral reflexes present bilaterally. Contralateral reflexes present when stimulating left, absent when stimulating right. Retrocochlear pathology not suspected due to recent neurology workup.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: BKB-SIN test used due to cognitive status (less taxing on memory). Performance was within normal limits.

tests.name: Client Oriented Scale of Improvement (COSI)
tests.key_findings: Patient identified four priority situations for communication improvement.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the low frequencies sloping to a moderate (right) to moderately-severe (left) high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Speech understanding in quiet is excellent (100%) and speech-in-noise performance on the BKB-SIN is within normal limits. Middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Although your hearing loss is mild, treating it is important because untreated hearing loss is a risk factor for cognitive decline.
Hearing aids can reduce the 'listening effort' your brain has to exert, freeing up resources for memory and processing.
We want to involve your wife in the process to help reduce the burden of repetition on her.
We will choose hearing aids that are simple to use (rechargeable) to minimize frustration.
I recommend a trial period with Receiver-In-The-Canal (RIC) hearing aids and attending group rehabilitation classes.
notes_for_actor: You are a high-functioning professional (court interpreter) who speaks 5 languages.
You are slightly in denial about your hearing ('I hear fine'), but you are very worried about your recent diagnosis of Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
You rely on your wife to fill in gaps in conversation.
You are motivated to try hearing aids primarily to protect your brain health and help your wife, rather than because you feel you can't hear.
